pros: Great team, benefits, pay, company values
cons:
Role is highly micromanaged, monotonous
Advice to Management
I know the role requires accountability and integrity and perhaps it is why micromanagement is passed down from director to manager to supervisor but it’s a tough environment to work in. Expectations and standards are high but non stop calling and taking calls while also expecting to complete all other tasks, and adhere to a schedule that is hard to control, but nearly impossible to update in system, then it shouldn’t be a metric. Place more emphasis on metrics then on just letting employees get their jobs done and provide good service and relationships with members. They can measure every single move you make which causes a lot of pressure to be perfect. Makes it challenging to always meet and exceed expectations when you feel like you’re under a constant microscope. Just thought I’d be helping people and selling but as I said, seem to care more about the metrics. Which can feel overwhelming and constraining but I get they have certain numbers to hit and it’s how their success is determined. They look at how much you sell a month and you need to speak to 8 people a day, which can take 50 calls and voicemails, you answer emails, chats, and complete several other tasks all while also taking inbounds and having no more than 2 minutes between calls. If there are inbound emails, they want you to finish in 5-7 minutes. Be prepared to screen share and have them listening in on calls. Quality department will also rate calls and you have to follow a call flow. Training is good and they do help if you need it but it is high pressure and fast paced and it can be mentally fatiguing. If you’re only 1 minute late, even from lunch or break, you get verbals. I haven’t been in call centers much but if you’re used to that, just know there are codes you go into to not get calls, but they monitor them heavily. They do ask for feedback so managers, please keep asking for feedback. The only bad thing is some feedback they will say there’s nothing they can do or will do. Sometimes there are system issues that make it challenging to sell but IT is responsive. Overall, great bosses and team mates, members are mostly in good spirits except during a pandemic, occasional rude customer but far and few in between. Call center work is hard for management to make it feel less routine and boring but they try. Retention basically does it all, we service and sell. Which can be rewarding but also what makes it hard because it’s a lot of multi tasking and you keep having to switch your hat. This was also my review but I’d say to management, I know there are reasons to essentially spy on employees but it makes it an overbearing environment. Also needing to make non stop phone calls, accept phone calls, wde emails, awds, regular emails, meetings, I drives, training, and complicated customer issues and also hit all metrics and exceed them just to try and get a better schedule or recognition, when it’s hard enough just to meet them...it can feel like we are expected to be machines or robo callers. Sometimes it’s going to take more time to notate or complete a task or work on policies or complex issues. It’s hard feeling like your every move is being watched or that you can get warnings or write ups for not meeting metrics when stuff comes up everyday. For people applying, if you have a hard time in fast paced environments, time management or multi tasking, this will be a challenge. Overall wonderful though and truly a great company that really cares. Working from home during Covid really made me feel safe. It’s a good opportunity and I will say, management is willing to listen so that can take you far.

Finally, toxic behavior and badmouthing should not be tolerated by even the "old-hands" at the company, let alone your younger FTE's because you might be surprised to find out that they might be the very ones holding back productivity and destroying morale. Wake up.

review_title: The FLRP program for MBAs is deceitful
pros:
- Many areas of Nationwide have work-life balance. The hours are good.
- Flexible work arrangements may be an option depending on your manager. There have been instances where Nationwide allows you to work remotely if your spouse moves for his job.
- The participants in FLRP are friendly and nice. Everyone says hello to one another. Most FLRPs try to help one another and are good colleagues.
- People from various departments and at various levels are willing to meet with you. These coffee chats are where they discuss their work. A main goal for FLRPs is to meet as many high level people as possible in the hope that they have a permanent role for you after FLRP.
cons:
- Deceitful recruitment in the sense that the FLRP program pitches itself to MBA candidates as a leadership program for those with relevant pre-MBA career experience and a way to accelerate your career. Many MBA FLRPs seem to have more leadership responsibility in their pre-MBA career than in FLRP or immediately after if they permanently stay at Nationwide.
- FLRP was founded in 2005. 15 years later in 2020, it seems to be riding on a reputation of former glory.
- Supervisors want to hire MBAs out the FLRP program but are complaining that they aren’t given the budget to create a permanent role for MBA FLRPs who they work with. It results in FLRPs being stuck in limbo where they may get a permanent role in the future from the supervisors they have worked with.
- FLRP MBAs have been backing out of their contracts recently and leaving Nationwide altogether within a few years or even more quickly.
- I was told many areas of Nationwide don’t have the budget or aren't allowed to hire MBA FLRPs for permanent roles even if they want to. Undergraduate FLRPs are cheaper for hiring managers because their salaries are lower than MBAs, which results in more post-FLRP job openings for undergraduate FLRPs.
- FLRP used to recruit from top 10 MBA programs such as Yale, Harvard, and Michigan in addition to the valedictorians from mid-tier MBA programs. However, all 20 of the FLRP MBAs from Yale, Harvard, and Michigan have left Nationwide. It is strange how rapidly top talent leaves Nationwide.
- If you want to work for Nationwide after MBA school, consider bypassing FLRP and applying directly to H-Band roles or Investment Professional roles straight out of MBA school. The risk of spending time in FLRP is it may leave you worse off and in a lower pay band or subject to an anxiety-filled placement process where you are in limbo while the FLRP program has no permanent role for you.
Advice to Management
- FLRP is losing high quality candidates to other employers. It’s a problem when more than half of the MBA FLRPs and internal FLRPs don’t place out of the FLRP program.
- It doesn’t seem to working for Nationwide to provide similar opportunities to FLRPs with vastly different opportunity sets, because the marketplace outside of Nationwide values these backgrounds differently.
